body_text.text: 1 Social preparedness in response to spatial distancing measures for aged care 1 during COVID-19 2 To the Editor 3

As cases and deaths from novel coronavirus (COVID-19) continue to rise exponentially, many 4 countries are employing increasingly tight lock-down and emergency procedures, including the rapid 5 implementation of spatial distancing measures. However, as we progress to more aggressive spatial 6 distancing processes, the coronavirus fallout threatens to cause a social crisis for already 7 disadvantaged populations, such as older individuals who are managing chronic illnesses and those 8 who are in receipt of aged care services. 9

Long-term effects of prolonged spatial distancing will likely affect this cohort, who may 10 already be, and are particularly vulnerable to social isolation, and have detrimental effects on their 11 physical and mental health 1 . This necessitates comprehensive strategies to address the social impact 12 of these changes. 13

We provide solutions towards integrating traditional and new social support structures to 14 manage the evolving pandemic in addressing the social needs of older individuals and highlight how 15 governments can manage and evaluate social preparedness for aged care. An investment now will 16 contribute to longer-term social benefits after spatial distancing requirements are over. 17

Research and resources now need to be placed on developing and adopting technology-19 based options to connect people in different places using both synchronous and asynchronous forms 20 of communication. 2 Population-based survey research supports the view that older adults are 21 increasingly adopting and using technology in their lives. 3,4 However, despite two-thirds of US seniors 22 owning smartphones and over 80% are Internet/social media users, adults over 80 years old barely 23 use technology-based communications, 5 and those in residential care have even more limited use. 6 24

To tackle the pandemic and bring forth the next era of digital inclusion, governments should 26 apply a Digital Education Revolution to support e-connections within aged care. In 2008, laptops 27 were provided to all Australian public high school students 7 . In 2020, supplying tablets to individual 28 residents, rapidly employing high speed broadband in facilities, and providing supportive 29 information and communication technology infrastructures and digital proficiency for both staff and 30 residents, is now essential. 31
body_text.section: Call to action for governments to be digitally inclusive 25

body_text.text: Residents will have varying needs and responses to technology, depending on their previous 32 technology use and adoption history, cognitive and functional status, and reliance on visitors and 33 group activities. Initial studies have shown great benefits, with residents successfully overcoming 34 loneliness, but effectiveness is limited by staff troubleshooting skills. Increasing staffing levels with 35 tech personnel will assist with the digital adoption process as aged care personnel will all be stressed 36 by the challenges of a prolonged response to COVID-19. 37
body_text.section: Call to action for governments to be digitally inclusive 25

body_text.text: These times are now demanding care workers to balance both residents' social needs 39 against personal risks and to develop alternative, age-friendly digital environments for residents to 40 maintain social contact with their families, other residents and staff whilst being spatially distant. 41
body_text.section: A trialling time for aged care 38

body_text.text: Providers can take immediate action by familiarising residents with existing, recognisable 42 and free video chat platforms (e.g., FaceTime) to engage in meaningful social exchange with family, 43 as well as prioritising engagement between residents. In the long-run, providers can recruit 44 community members to assist with traditional phone check ins to at-risk individuals and introduce 45 residents to apps that increase individual personal wellbeing, physical activity, brain health and 46 personal interests. Websites now host free 'virtual' galleries of international museums and physical 3 activity classes, which will be particularly useful in tackling physical deconditioning, a condition likely 48 to occur. 49
body_text.section: A trialling time for aged care 38

body_text.text: More original ideas will surface as we embrace these changes. It is pertinent that this 50 information is widely distributed so improvements and adoptions can be made globally. Sharing 51 positive experiences in the affected communities are also key to connecting with one another, which 52 can also support individual recovery and resilience in the long-term. Research should also focus on 53 evaluating the effectiveness of different technologies and policies used to inform future pandemics. 54
body_text.section: A trialling time for aged care 38

body_text.text: Telemedicine has been a critical part of communication during this pandemic, with patients 56 being increasingly screened over the phone. Further use of telemedicine to specifically prevent or 57 limit adverse health and mental impacts of social isolation in residents will be invaluable, especially 58 those with chronic conditions that usually have frequent healthcare visits ordinarily. 59

To become a stronger, more resilient society both during and after the outbreak, we must 61 focus on rebuilding central social foundations for vulnerable individuals in an innovative way. Once 62 this viral crisis is over, our hope is that we do not forget the lessons learned about the value of 63 creating and sustaining meaningful relationships with our oldest members of the public. 64
